The prisons, banishment, and police are strong enough. There’s no need to worry. You just have to catch the thief.

‘And what happens if we catch him?’

‘Then he gets what he deserves.’

‘You’re very logical. But what about his conscience?’

‘Why do you care about that?’

‘Just because I care about people.’

‘If he has a conscience, he will feel bad for what he did. That will be his punishment, along with going to prison.’

‘But what about the real geniuses,’ Razumihin asked with a frown, ‘the ones who have the right to kill? Shouldn’t they feel bad for the blood they’ve spilled?’

‘Why say "should"? It’s not about permission. He will feel pain if he regrets his victim. Pain and suffering always come with a smart mind and a caring heart. I believe that great men must feel a lot of sadness in life,’ he said, sounding dreamy and not really in line with the conversation.

He looked at everyone seriously, smiled, and picked up his cap. He felt quieter than when he first came in, and he noticed it. Everyone stood up.

‘You can criticize me or be mad at me if you want,’ Porfiry Petrovitch started again, ‘but I can’t help it. Let me ask you one small question (I know I’m bothering you). There’s just one little idea I want to share so I don’t forget it.’

‘Okay, tell me your little idea,’ Raskolnikov said, waiting, looking pale and serious.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The conversation explores the relationship between crime, conscience, and the inevitable suffering of those who commit acts of violence, particularly focusing on the moral implications for "great men."
